question: Which factors directly control the *rate* at which the freshwater–saltwater interface moves inland under sea-level rise? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Higher T and lower S accelerate movement, and L sets the spatial response scale.

question: In the Glover–Morgan equation, what does the term $X_f$ represent? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. $X_f$ is the final equilibrium displacement after the boundary change.
error: ❌ Recall: $X_f$ is the asymptotic value reached as time → ∞.

question: Why might the Glover–Morgan model underestimate intrusion in real-world cases? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Real aquifers have dispersion, heterogeneity, and other stresses that speed intrusion.
error: ❌ Review the simplifying assumptions — they often cause underestimation in complex systems.

question: If transmissivity increases while all else stays the same, what happens to the inland movement rate predicted by Glover–Morgan? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Higher T allows the aquifer to respond more quickly to head changes.
error: ❌ Higher T means water can move more easily, speeding up the interface adjustment.

question: Which assumption is common to both Ghyben–Herzberg and Glover–Morgan models? (Mark ALL correct answers)
